'''Standelf''' was a small village in the southern regions of [[Buckland]].<ref>{{FR|Part}}</ref>
==Other versions of the Legendarium==
In a draft of ''[[A Conspiracy Unmasked]]'', Standelf is mentioned once (while it is never mentioned in the published text of ''[[The Lord of the Rings]]'') as traversed by the road "from the [[Brandywine Bridge|Bridge]] to Standelf and [[Haysend]]". In the final map, the road stops at Standelf and doesn't continue to Haysend.<ref>{{RS|2XVIII1}}, pp. 298-9</ref>
==Etymology==
The name means "Stone-delving", from [[Old English]] ''st√°n'' "stone" and ''delf'' "a delving or burrow".<ref>{{RS|2XVIIN}}, Note 5</ref>

[[David Salo]] suggests the "Old Hobbitish" form of the name was ''Stangedelf''.<ref>{{webcite|author=[[David Salo]]|articleurl=https://tolkienlistsearch.herokuapp.com/message/5e9c35b63ee6a6c41e9862d6|articlename=Hobbitish Place-names|dated=23 November 1998|website=[[Elfling]]|accessed=14 April 2014}}</ref>
==Inspiration==
There is a place called Stonydelph in Warwickshire of the same etymology.<ref name=rc>{{HM|RC}}, p. lix</ref>
